animalOfTheDay.name: anteater
facts: Giant anteaters can consume up to 30,000 ants and termites per day.
They have no teeth but use their sticky 2-foot-long tongues to catch prey.
Their sense of smell is 40 times stronger than humans.
Baby anteaters ride on their mother's back for up to 10 months.

calendar.name: yak
facts: Yaks survive at 20,000 ft – lungs and hearts 3x larger than cattle.
They grunt instead of mooing; 'yak' mimics their guttural sounds.
Their dung is dried and burned as fuel in treeless Himalayan regions.
Yak milk is rich in butterfat – churned into butter tea in Tibet.

calendar.name: yellowfin tuna
facts: They hunt in coordinated schools, herding prey toward the surface.
Their fins glow yellow when excited – a display during feeding frenzies.
Yellowfins maintain muscle temperature above water via specialized blood vessels.
Yellowfin tuna can reach 50 mph – among the fastest fish.

calendar.name: zebu
facts: Their loose skin helps dissipate heat in tropical climates.
Zebus have humps storing fat for drought survival – not water.
Zebu are sacred in India – 330 million gods are said to live in each.
They sweat insect-repellent oils and tolerate heat better than European cattle.

calendar.name: zonkey
facts: Their bray combines zebra whinny and donkey 'hee-haw'.
Zonkeys are sterile due to mismatched chromosomes.
They inherit donkey calmness with zebra hardiness against diseases.
Zonkeys are zebra-donkey hybrids; stripes typically appear only on legs.

calendar.name: aardvark
facts: Aardvarks can eat up to 50,000 ants and termites in a single night.
Their name comes from Afrikaans meaning 'earth pig' though they're not related to pigs.
They have incredibly strong claws that can dig through concrete.
Baby aardvarks are called cubs and stay with their mothers for about 6 months.

calendar.name: alligator
facts: A mother alligator carries her babies to water in her mouth after they hatch.
They're one of the few animals that continue growing throughout their entire lives.
They can survive up to 2-3 years without eating in extreme conditions.
Alligators can hold their breath underwater for up to 24 hours.

calendar.name: anteater
facts: Giant anteaters can consume up to 30,000 ants and termites per day.
Baby anteaters ride on their mother's back for up to 10 months.
Their sense of smell is 40 times stronger than humans.
They have no teeth but use their sticky 2-foot-long tongues to catch prey.

randomAnimals.name: sea turtle
facts: Sea turtles can migrate thousands of miles between feeding and nesting grounds.
They return to the same beach where they were born to lay their eggs.
The temperature of the nest determines the gender of the hatchlings.
Leatherback sea turtles can dive deeper than 1,000 meters (3,280 feet).

randomAnimals.name: fennec fox
facts: No facts available.

randomAnimals.name: squirrel monkey
facts: Squirrel monkeys are small, agile monkeys from Central and South America, known for their white 'mask' around their eyes.
They feed on insects, fruits, nuts, and bird eggs.
They live in large social groups, numbering up to 500 individuals, and are very active during the day.
They have very long tails that help them maintain balance, but they are not prehensile.
